title: Neuromyelitis Optica Presenting as Subacute Lower Limb Weakness in a Middle-Aged Woman
clinical_history: Ms. Patricia Gomez is a 43-year-old accountant who presented with sudden onset of severe bilateral leg weakness and numbness. Three weeks ago, she developed blurred vision in her right eye accompanied by ocular pain, which improved partially but not completely. Over the past 7 days, she progressively lost strength in both legs, struggling to stand from sitting and needing a walker for short distances. She describes numbness from her abdomen down and an inability to sense bladder fullness, resulting in two episodes of urinary incontinence. She reports persistent tightness and aching in her lower back, hips, and thighs. No significant trauma or recent illness. Patricia is anxious due to her loss of independence and concerned about keeping up with her work and caring for her teenage son.

nprs.affected_area: bilateral lower limb musculature (hip flexors, quadriceps, hamstrings)
lower back paraspinals (secondary complaint of tightness/ache)

aggrevating_factors: Prolonged sitting, attempting to stand or walk without support, transfers from bed to chair, and climbing stairs worsen pain and exacerbate spasticity.
picture: [image depicting bilateral lower limb weakness and patchy sensory loss below the thoracic spine, right optic disc swelling]
easing_factors: Resting in semi-reclined position, application of warm compresses to thighs and lower back, and passive range of motion exercises reduce muscular discomfort.
past_history: Unremarkable. No known autoimmune or neurological history prior to the current episode.
medical_history: Mild hypertension, managed with diet. Family history negative for neurological disease.
medications: Oral prednisone started 5 days ago (1 mg/kg), baclofen 10 mg BID for spasticity, acetaminophen PRN for pain.
personal_history: Lives with her 16-year-old son. Recently divorced. Non-smoker, minimal alcohol use, works from home. Stresses related to work deadlines and family changes.
imaging: Spinal MRI shows longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis (T2 hyperintensity extending from T4-T10 levels), and brain MRI unremarkable except for right optic nerve swelling. Serum aquaporin-4 antibody positive.
